timeline.summary: This document is a questionnaire for United States Attorneys’ Offices and the Executive Office for United States Attorneys regarding foreign travel. It outlines a series of steps and questions to be addressed before travel, including: *   **Travel Details:** Collecting traveler information like name, position, destination, dates, and passport details. *   **Reservations & Approvals:** Requiring confirmed flight itineraries, lodging, and approval from OIA (Office of Inter-Agency Liaison Affairs) and potentially the State Department (eCC clearance). *   **Security & Training:** Assessing traveler security clearance levels, completion of HTSOS and FACT training, and addressing high-threat area travel. *   **Specific Case Questions:** Gathering details about the purpose of travel, case specifics (e.g., witness interviews, depositions), and potential involvement of foreign authorities. *   **Submission Process:** Specifies how to submit the completed questionnaire and attachments for approval. The document covers both general foreign travel and specific questions related to travel for conference/training events or travel to countries other than Canada for judicial assistance matters.

A questionnaire titled “Questionnaire for Official Foreign Travel” was sent by an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York to an individual, likely related to a case involving EFTA00028457, on January 24, 2020. The questionnaire is attached as “Questionnairefor_Official_Foreign_Travel,_Stocltholm,2020iM).pdf”.

An email was sent on January 24, 2020, from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding a questionnaire titled "Questionnaire_for_Official_Foreign_Travel_Stockholm_2020a.pdf." The email subject was "Questionnaire - Hi We also need this one ASAP. Thanks," and the importance was marked as High. The email included attachments related to EFTA00020858.

An email chain discusses a revised travel itinerary. One individual ([REDACTED]) sent a questionnaire ([Questionnairefor_Official_Foreign_Travel,Stockholm,2020_ .pdf]) to another ([REDACTED]) due to an issue with the original itinerary, which is now being cancelled and replaced with a different flight.

Travel authorization 10982121 was approved for a trip to Stockholm, Sweden from February 3rd to February 6th, 2020, for the purpose of witness interviews related to the Epstein investigation (R20NYS 13341 - 2018R01618). The approval was granted by an individual redacted from the email, and the authorization is currently pending further approval. Relevant login information for the E2 Solutions system is provided.

An email request is being submitted for travel to Stockholm, Sweden, for an Assistant U.S. Attorney and two other individuals (AUSAs S and S) by the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York. The request includes an ECC package (ECC_package_2.3.2.20.pdf) and instructions for the traveler to determine the Point of Contact (POC), check for visa requirements via the State Department’s website, and submit the visa request package to EOUSA-RMP Travel at least 15 business days prior to departure to allow sufficient time for State Dept. authorization and foreign government processing. The delay in submission is due to a recently confirmed witness interview date.

An email chain discusses travel plans to Stockholm, Sweden, from February 3-7 for an interview related to the Epstein investigation. The sender, an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York, requests approval and additional information or materials. The email thread confirms the travel is authorized and sets the stage for separate phone requests.

Travel authorization 10982117 was approved for an investigation into Epstein, with a destination of Stockholm, Sweden, from February 3rd to February 7th, 2020. The current status is pending further authorization approval. The email also includes standard disclaimers about confidential information and E2Solutions support resources. Reference ID# T0007 is associated with this communication.

A travel authorization was approved for a trip to Stockholm, Sweden, from February 3rd to February 8th, 2020, for the purpose of witness interviews related to the Epstein investigation (R20NYS 13342 - 2018R01618). The authorization was issued by [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] and is currently pending further approval. The email includes login information for E2 Single Sign On and E2 Manual Login, along with standard confidentiality disclaimers and a reference ID# T0007.

Travel authorization 10982117 was approved for an investigation trip to Stockholm, Sweden, from February 3rd to February 8th, 2020, regarding witness interviews (R20NYS 13342 - Epstein investigation). The trip is pending further authorization approval. Relevant links for E2 Single Sign On and manual login are provided. Reference ID# T0007 is associated with this authorization.

Travel authorization 10982122 was approved for an investigation trip to Stockholm, Sweden, from February 3rd to February 6th, 2020, related to the Epstein investigation (R20NYS 13340). The trip’s purpose was witness interviews. The authorization is currently pending further approval. Relevant login links and contact information for E2Solutions support are provided. Reference ID# T0007 is also included.

Travel authorization 10982122 has been approved for a trip to Stockholm, Sweden from February 3rd to February 6th, 2020, for the purpose of witness interviews related to the Epstein investigation (R20NYS 13340 - 2018R01618). The authorization is currently pending further approval. Relevant login links and contact information are provided, along with a disclaimer regarding confidential email content. Reference ID# T0007 is also included.

Travel authorization 10982121 was approved for an investigation (R20NYS 13341 - Epstein investigation) involving witness interviews in Stockholm, Sweden, from February 3rd to 6th, 2020. The authorization is currently pending further approval. Relevant login links and contact information for E2Solutions support are provided. Reference ID# T0007 is associated with this authorization.

Travel authorization 10982122 for the purpose of witness interviews related to the Epstein investigation (R20NYS 13340 - 2018R01618) has been approved. The trip to Stockholm, Sweden, from February 3rd to 6th, 2020, was authorized for the traveler, OBD-USA-USANYS-NEW YORK SOUTHERN (UNYS) (JO2104), and the minor customer, and uses the E2 Solutions travel system with associated login links.  The email includes standard confidentiality and notification management information.

Travel authorization 10982122 was approved for a trip to Stockholm, Sweden from February 3rd to February 6th, 2020, for the purpose of witness interviews related to the Epstein investigation (R20NYS 13340 - 2018R01618). The authorization is currently pending approval. Relevant login links and contact information for support are provided. Reference ID# T0007 is associated with this authorization.

A final voucher (Voucher ID: 1) for travel expenses related to an Epstein investigation (“R20NYS 13340”) is pending review. The trip, to Stockholm, Sweden, from February 3rd to 6th, 2020, had a current total expense of 2143.49 and an estimated cost of 2954.54. The voucher was prepared by a travel arranger and is accessible through E2 Solutions.  The sender provides login information and cautions about unmonitored replies and the potential for confidential information. Reference ID# V0012 is associated with the document.

This document consists of email exchanges related to travel requests for interviews and investigations, primarily concerning the Epstein case (2018R01618). Multiple requests are made for travel to Pensacola, FL, Stockholm, Sweden, Los Angeles, and West Palm Beach, Florida, involving teams of individuals. These requests include specific flight details (e.g., American Airlines flights with layovers), requests for refundable tickets, and the need for conference room reservations. The emails highlight a persistent pattern of travel requests tied to the Epstein investigation and demonstrate a need for logistical coordination regarding flight bookings, timing, and accommodation.

Multiple requests are being submitted for travel approvals to conduct interviews related to the Epstein investigation (2018R01618). These requests involve travel to locations including Pensacola, Florida; Stockholm, Sweden; Los Angeles, California; West Palm Beach, Florida, and Fort Lauderdale, Florida.  Each request involves a team of individuals and requests approval for a conference room during the interviews. The requests consistently reference prior similar investigations and prioritize minimizing travel time.  Cost-conscious booking options are requested.

Email communication regarding approved voucher 10982122(1) for a trip to Stockholm, Sweden from February 3rd to February 6th, 2020, for the purpose of witness interviews related to the Epstein investigation (R20NYS 13340 - 2018R01618). The voucher total expenses were 2143.49, and the estimated trip cost was 2954.54. The voucher is currently pending approval. The email includes links to E2 Single Sign On and E2 Manual Login systems.

The document is a redacted email chain concerning travel requests for investigations related to the Epstein case (2018R01618). Multiple requests are made for travel to Pensacola, Florida, Los Angeles, Stockholm, Sweden, and potentially other locations, primarily for interviews and conference room bookings.  The requests consistently involve American Airlines flights, specific dates, and a need for refundable tickets.  A recurring theme is seeking approval for travel expenses and conference room reservations due to ongoing investigative work.  The emails detail scheduling difficulties, flight changes, and attempts to secure the most cost-effective and refundable options.

The document consists of a series of email exchanges requesting travel approvals for investigations, primarily related to the Epstein case (2018R01618). The requests consistently involve travel to Los Angeles, West Palm Beach, and potentially Stockholm, Sweden, for interviews with victims and witnesses.  A recurring request is for approval to secure conference rooms at hotels during these trips. The emails highlight a need for flexibility in scheduling and an interest in minimizing travel time and costs, often specifying domestic or domestic-flagged carrier flights. Redactions obscure specific details within the emails.

The document consists of a series of emails requesting travel approvals for investigations related to the Epstein case (2018R01618).  These requests involve travel to locations including Los Angeles, Stockholm, West Palm Beach, and Fort Lauderdale, Florida, primarily for interviews.  The requests consistently involve a team of individuals, seek approval for hotel bookings and conference rooms, and specify expected travel dates with flexible timelines.  The emails repeatedly reference prior similar requests and a desire for domestic-flagged carrier flights to minimize costs.  The content is heavily redacted.

The documents detail repeated requests for travel approval for interviews related to the Epstein investigation (2018R01618). These requests involve travel to Los Angeles, Stockholm, West Palm Beach, and potentially Fort Lauderdale, Florida. The team consistently seeks permission for flights, hotel reservations (including conference rooms) for these interviews, and favors domestic-flagged carrier flights. The requests are often linked to prior investigations and involve multiple individuals coordinating travel arrangements and confirming scheduling details.

This document consists of a series of email exchanges regarding travel approvals for investigative work, primarily related to the Epstein investigation (2018R01618). The core requests involve travel to locations including Pensacola, Florida, Los Angeles, Stockholm, Sweden, and West Palm Beach/Fort Lauderdale, Florida, for interviews with witnesses. Flight options, particularly refundable domestic flights versus nonrefundable ones, are frequently discussed. Hotel bookings and conference room reservations are also repeatedly requested, often with specific time constraints. The emails highlight a need to coordinate schedules, consider alternative flight options, and manage expenses related to the investigation.

A recurring request is made for permission to travel to locations including Pensacola, Florida, Los Angeles, Stockholm, and West Palm Beach to conduct interviews with witnesses. Key elements consistently requested are refundable flight options (particularly avoiding penalty fares), a preference for “unrestricted coach” fares, and the reservation of conference rooms at hotels for the interviews.  The requests involve multiple individuals and agencies, including the U.S. Attorney’s Office and Legal Assistants. There are repeated requests to shorten the travel timeframe based on scheduling constraints.

This document contains a series of email exchanges related to travel requests for investigative purposes, primarily linked to the Epstein investigation (2018R01618). The requests involve travel to various locations including Pensacola, Florida, Stockholm, Sweden, Los Angeles, and West Palm Beach, Florida, for witness interviews. Flight options are repeatedly proposed, often with refundable options being highlighted. Hotel accommodations, particularly at the Hilton Garden Inn (specifically the “HGI PENSACOLA AIRPORT MEDICAL” location), and conference room bookings are consistently requested, often with specific dates and durations. There's a recurring need to secure domestic-flagged carrier flights and consideration for costs. The travel arrangements are driven by scheduling conflicts, witness availability, and the need for a brief, focused investigative period.

Multiple individuals within the U.S. Attorney’s Office (SDNY) are requesting permission and arrangements for travel to Pensacola, Florida, Los Angeles, and Stockholm, Sweden, primarily for conducting interviews with witnesses. Key elements of the requests include: *   **Flight Details:** Specific flight codes (e.g., Delta JFK to PNS) are proposed, with some flights being refundable and others not. *   **Hotel Booking:** Requests are made for hotel accommodations, specifically the Hilton Garden Inn (PNS Airport Medical). *   **Conference Room Requests:** Requests for conference room bookings at the hotel locations for interview sessions are consistently made. *   **Penalty Fare Avoidance:** Guidance is provided on avoiding penalty fares by selecting “unrestricted coach” fare options. *   **Scheduling Flexibility:** The requests emphasize a need for flexible scheduling to accommodate witness availability. *   **Recurring Requests:** The travel requests are part of a pattern of similar requests related to the Epstein investigation.

This document is a series of email exchanges requesting travel approvals for interviews related to the Epstein investigation (2018R01618). The requests involve travel to Pensacola, Florida, Stockholm, Sweden, Los Angeles, and West Palm Beach, Florida, typically for two to three days, to interview witnesses. Consistent requests are made for conference room reservations at various hotels during these trips.  Recurring details include the need for domestic-flagged flights, tax exempt forms, and coordinating with specific individuals (M, and/or). The emails demonstrate a pattern of repeated requests for similar travel arrangements across multiple dates and locations.

This document is a series of email exchanges related to travel requests for interviews and conference room bookings, primarily concerning the Epstein investigation (2018R01618). The requests consistently involve travel to locations like Pensacola, Florida, Los Angeles, Stockholm, and West Palm Beach. The requests repeatedly seek approval for travel dates, flights, and a conference room reservation for interviews.  A recurring theme is the need to secure flights (often Delta) and a conference room, and a request for cost-consciousness in booking options. The requests are submitted by U.S. Attorneys and Legal Assistants seeking approval and assistance with logistics.

An email was sent from etravelservices to [REDACTED] regarding Final Voucher 10982122(1), approved for a trip to Stockholm, Sweden from February 3rd to 6th, 2020, for the purpose of the Epstein investigation. The trip total expenses were $2143.49, with an estimated cost of $2954.54. The voucher status is pending approval. The email includes links to E2 Single Sign On and E2 Manual Login, and a disclaimer regarding confidential information. Reference ID# V0010 is also included.

Final voucher 10982122(1) has been approved for travel to Stockholm, Sweden from February 3rd to 6th, 2020. The trip was for the purpose of witness interviews related to the Epstein investigation (R20NYS 13340 - 2018R01618). The traveler is associated with OBD-USA-USANYS-NEW YORK SOUTHERN (UNYS) (JO2104). The total expenses were 2143.49, with an estimated trip cost of 2954.54. The voucher’s current status is awaiting payment.  Links to E2 Single Sign On and E2 Manual Login are provided.

John Ray and his partner, Madeleine Kristoffersson, are providing information regarding an investigation into Jeffrey Epstein. They claim to be the source of the information and state that Kristoffersson was involved with Epstein, receiving $150,000 through shell entities for her daughters. They provide details about social media activity, photos of Epstein with young men (including Hazeltine), and indicate Kristoffersson slipped into the US from Stockholm. Ray requests confidentiality for Kristoffersson and seeks to have her considered a person of interest. The Assistant U.S. Attorney requests clarification on the source of the information and inquires about any allegations of underage involvement.

*   **Complainant Account:** A woman (identified as redacted) who claims to have been introduced to Epstein by a Canadian friend in 2002-2004. *   **Complainant Activity:** The woman facilitated meetings between Epstein and underage aspiring models, allegedly procuring them for sex trafficking with Epstein and Maxwell’s involvement. She described receiving money from Epstein for her services. *   **Witness Information:** A 40-year-old witness, also redacted, who identifies themselves as the complainant’s friend. *   **Technical Data:** The tip originated from an IP address in Stockholm, Sweden.  The user browser and referrer were also recorded.
